text:
If it's a regular thing that sounds like something worth mentioning to her superior(s).

A manager should be helping you hit + exceed your targets, not putting you down when asking how you can improve and making you afraid to reach out to her for assistance.

If it was a one-off it could be that you just caught her on a bad day, but it doesn't sound like that from what you've written...

elements.text:

text:
Your manager is 100% completely and totally out of line. It sounds like she is responding from a place of frustration which is just never ever a good thing.

I wouldn't attempt to change anything about your behavior until you have the conversation <@URAV154AV> outlined above which is phenomenal advice.

Have the hard conversation. Let her know how it impacts you and that you're open to constructive feedback, but her comments feel personal and ruin your productivity.

Escalate to her manager if needed because again, she's in the wrong here. I cannot think of a single scenario in which a manager should say these words to their direct report.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: <@U011QQDDSJV> this might be an obvious question, but have you asked her, specifically, _where_ she tends to get stuck when, for example, putting together a brief? Knowing where the specific "blockers" are might help you develop some OKRs that are more targeted to the actual problem, and more useful to your direct report in helping to solve the disconnect.

elements.text: this might be an obvious question, but have you asked her, specifically,

she tends to get stuck when, for example, putting together a brief? Knowing where the specific "blockers" are might help you develop some OKRs that are more targeted to the actual problem, and more useful to your direct report in helping to solve the disconnect.

text: In my experience, both as a writer and as a manager, time-bound OKRs for writing-based tasks are a nightmare to manage/track against. That goes double for an agency environment, because there's so much variation from project to project (and you're very often learning new material as you go)

elements.text: In my experience, both as a writer and as a manager, time-bound OKRs for writing-based tasks are a nightmare to manage/track against. That goes double for an agency environment, because there's so much variation from project to project (and you're very often learning new material as you go)

text: At Animalz, we set a lot of process-based OKRs - i.e. if we want the content manager's writing to require fewer edits, we set an OKR to "create a self editing checklist and go through it on each draft before submitting". "objective" is the big-picure thing we want (fewer edits) - the "key results" are proactive steps the writer can take that help solve toward that goal

text:
This is really great. Thx <@UJ48Q1HAP>. I’ve had some version of this conversation with her, and I think she has a big confidence issue (she second-guesses her work, then lingers on it).

I tell her that I’m OK with imperfection in the interest of keeping the bigger project moving (I QC and edit her work anyhow). But that runs the risk of me doing her work, which my boss explicitly doesn’t want me to do.

We also have a pretty relaxed remote environment, where we’re not expected to be online during a hard schedule, so long as we get our work done within the scoped hours. I think there’s a little bit of time mgmt discipline on her end, and sometimes she kicks the can down the road knowing that our deadlines are usually EOM. Trying to tighten all that up.

I think there’s a little bit of time mgmt discipline on her end, and sometimes she kicks the can down the road knowing that our deadlines are usually EOM. Trying to tighten all that up.

text: Yikes. I can’t believe you need to deal with that. I get the sense you’re not actually causing her distress--it’s someone or something else. If this is ongoing, it’s a major character flaw. Look for a new job where you’ll be appreciated.
